narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The best thing I learned from this course was how to structure my own stories and how to parse other stories' structures. Before entering this class, I knew a little bit about the three-act structure, but beyond that, I didn't know much. Camille helped us dissect existing films and screenplays so that we could then use these structural tools and apply them to our own screenplays. I absolutely see myself using this information in the future.
I learned how to parse films and create film script. I have a much more technical understanding of the art of film.
we worked on writing screenplays
How to write a screenplay, formatting, marks in films, theme, motif

How to parse screenplays, how screenwriting differs from other types of narrative writing, how to write a screenplay from scratch (plot, pacing, character development, symbols, themes, etc.), and how to distill big story ideas to a clear, effective plot. We watched several filmsboth during and outside of classto learn storytelling techniques in the visual medium and how to apply them to our own screenplays.

Ostensibly I learned a lot about screenplay writing, but I really felt like I took away a better understanding of storytelling and narrative in general. We read books like The Actor and the Target, which helped with dialogue writing, and parsed screenplays by breaking them down into story beats, which helped me see the underlying construction of most of the stories I encounter.

I learned SO much in this course, not only about screenwriting and film analysis but about how to look at the world, interpret the world, and even create a new one. We learned the basic structure of screenplays and "beat sheets" and parsed films to find the plot points. Analyzing films gave us the conceptual knowledge necessary to begin writing our own screenplay. When writing, I learned how be concise with my language and to think outside the box.
I acquired a great deal of knowledge about screenwriting and storytelling in general. I sharpened my analytical skills and learned so much about world-building.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Camille is, of course, the greatest strength of this course. She is a fantastic professor. She is always available to help students and she is eager to provide feedback that will improve your story and your writing. She treats each student's story seriously and provides many opportunities for one-on-one discussions during office hours. She also gave me the tools to recognize when I needed to change certain aspects of my story. Although my screenplay is still very much a work-in-progress, I plan on using her guidance for a long time!

I also enjoyed exchanging writing and feedback with my peers.
It's phenomenal. Camille is so passionate and caring. The class is so rewarding.
Great course all around.

Strengths: starts from zero, assumes no previous knowledge
Weaknesses: none

Strengths: Basically everythingthe professor, the syllabus, the peers, etc. Professor Thomasson truly cares about each and every student, and you get a lot of one-on-one attention to ameliorate your story. She translated the seminar into the virtual format really well. Every assignment was clearly laid out on Canvas, so there was little to no confusion about deadlines. The peers were also amazing; the seminar was made of students from all different undergraduate majors, and everyone had such an incredible story to tell. I personally found the peer-review screenplay sessions super productive and very helpful for brainstorming plot points/details.

Weaknesses: Perhaps one or two more of the peer-review screenplay sessions wouldve been the cherry on top.

I loved this course with my whole heart and its strengths were many. The lectures were creative, informative, and encouraged participation, the group work assignments were challenging but unique enough that they didn't feel difficult, and I loved how all the homework assignments fed into the eventual project of writing the first fifteen pages of an original screenplay. I'm having a hard time pointing out areas for improvement. Personally I enjoyed that sometimes the beginning of class consisted of cryptic poetry and clips from which we had to surmise the topic of the class -- it kept me on my toes -- but that might not appeal to everyone.
The class is already perfect. I don't see how it could be improved.

This is the best course I have ever taken at Yale. Prof. Thomasson was THE most supportive, knowledgeable, kind, and engaging instructor. The films we watch, parse, and analyze are fascinating and there is nothing more satisfying than creating part of a screenplay that YOU wrote. My classmates were also so supportive of everybody in the class. Everybody wanted everybody to succeed and create the story of their dreams. No weaknesses.

There are so many strengths! The feedback delivered to us was consistently crafted with so much care and thought. The structure of the class made each meeting absolutely compelling. You will leave each class session feeling more confident and assured as a writer and thinker. I honestly cannot think of a single weakness.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor was very careful to make the course as "normal" as possible, and it worked well in her favor.

Overall, the seminar translated well into the virtual format. Since it was a seminar, I really appreciated Professor Thomassons efforts to get everyone to talk and contribute to class discussions by having cameras and audio turned on. Having each weeks assignments clearly listed in Canvas Modules was very helpful and reduced a lot of unnecessary anxiety about deadlines. There were a couple of Zoom-related snags, but most issues were resolved pretty quickly.

The slides were well formatted and we were able to have discussions successfully. The chat was sometimes disabled, sometimes enabled only between the students and Professor Thomasson, and sometimes enabled for public messages but not private ones. I personally enjoy adding comments in the chat about the subject material and would have liked the chat to be consistently enabled for public messages, but I can also see how excess commenting might be distracting.
This course was the most successfully adapted course I've taken. We met once a week virtually, but the activities made it feel like we were in person. We even put on a PLAY!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely. If you are serious about screenwriting and are considering it as a career, take this course. If you are just looking for a fun writing/film class, take this course. You learn a lot and you have a good time doing it.
Yes; it's phenomenal for all the reasons mentioned above. Camille is great. Her class is too.
I'd recommend this course to anyone with an inkling to write a screenplay regardless of their major. My favorite course at Yale.
Would recommend.
YES. Professor Thomasson does everything in her power to help her students fulfill their talents and visions

This class is an ~experience~. If you are fortunate enough to have the opportunity to take this course sometime during your time at Yale, please do. All the professors at Yale are amazing in their own way, but Professor Thomasson truly has a gift for teaching. Every week, she prepares a well-thought-out presentation and shows us the perfect collection of films that demonstrates some element of screenwriting. At one-on-one office hours, she really gets to know you and helps you examine the story youre trying to tell from the macro to the micro. She has a brilliant intuition for finding the ingredients of a compelling story, so even if you go into this course with a barebone premise, shell help you crystalize it into a coherent plot.

If youve ever had the briefest inkling of a story you think might look good on the silver screen, please do yourself a favor and apply to this seminar.

I would definitely recommend this course. When I started I had never written a screenplay before, and I was the writing equivalent of a shower singer -- I wrote short stories in my free time but never showed them to anyone else. This class made me feel confident enough to pursue screenplay writing in further classes, and I enjoyed the course itself immensely. Professor Thomasson is wildly charismatic -- her expectations are high in the best of ways, and she is so very kind. All of our reading material felt necessary and held my attention consistently. Even on Zoom, Professor Thomasson helped us connect with each other and engage with the material every week. One of my favorite courses at Yale.

Absolutely. Professor Thomasson is the best teacher I've had at Yale; she has a deep understanding of story telling and craft, gives excellent feedback, and has been an invaluable guide. Everyone with any interest in writing should take this course.
Yes. Take it. Please. You will be eternally grateful for it.
Please do yourself a favor and take this course! I cannot recommend it enough! Just incredible on so many levels.
